title: Ian Jones (sportsman, born 1934)
text:
Charles Ian McMillan Jones, <a href="Royal%20Society%20of%20Arts">FRSA</a> (born 11 October 1934) is an English sportsman and academic who served as teacher and educational administrator from 1960 to 1997. He played <a href="cricket">cricket</a> between 1959 and 1969, including the <a href="1969%20Gillette%20Cup">1969 Gillette Cup</a> and was also an <a href="Olympic%20Games">Olympic</a> <a href="field%20hockey">field hockey</a> player, representing Britain at the <a href="1960%20Summer%20Olympics">1960</a> and the <a href="1964%20Summer%20Olympics">1964 Summer Olympics</a>.
Biography.
Born in United Kingdom's third-largest city, <a href="Leeds">Leeds</a>, Ian Jones was educated at <a href="Bishop%27s%20Stortford%20College">Bishop's Stortford College</a> and at <a href="St%20John%27s%20College%2C%20Cambridge">St John's College, Cambridge</a>. He was a <a href="second%20lieutenant">second lieutenant</a> in the <a href="Royal%20Artillery">Royal Artillery</a>, between 1953 and 1955, head of the geography department at <a href="Bishop%27s%20Stortford%20College">Bishop's Stortford College</a>, between 1960 and 1970, and vice-principal of <a href="King%20William%27s%20College">King William's College</a>, between 1971 and 1975. He was <a href="headmaster">headmaster</a> of <a href="Bedford%20School">Bedford School</a>, between 1975 and 1986, director of studies at <a href="Britannia%20Royal%20Naval%20College">Britannia Royal Naval College</a>, between 1986 and 1988, and project director at <a href="CfBT%20Education%20Trust">CfBT Education Trust</a>, between 1988 and 1997.
Cricket.
Jones' <a href="Batsman%20%28cricket%29">batting</a> style remains to be described, but it is known that he bowled right-arm <a href="Seam%20bowling">medium pace</a>. He made his <a href="first-class%20cricket">first-class</a> debut for <a href="Cambridge%20University%20Cricket%20Club">Cambridge University</a> against <a href="Worcestershire%20County%20Cricket%20Club">Worcestershire</a> in 1959. He batted once in this match, in the course of which he was dismissed for a <a href="duck%20%28cricket%29">duck</a> by <a href="Derek%20Pearson">Derek Pearson</a>. He made a further first-class appearance for the university, which came in that season against <a href="Middlesex%20County%20Cricket%20Club">Middlesex</a>. In this match, Jones was dismissed for a duck in the Cambridge first-innings by <a href="Robert%20Caple">Robert Caple</a>, while in their second-innings he scored 44 runs before being dismissed by <a href="Bob%20Hurst">Bob Hurst</a>.
In 1959, Jones made his debut for <a href="Hertfordshire%20County%20Cricket%20Club">Hertfordshire</a> against <a href="Cambridgeshire%20County%20Cricket%20Club">Cambridgeshire</a> in the <a href="Minor%20Counties%20Championship">Minor Counties Championship</a>. He played <a href="Minor%20counties%20of%20English%20and%20Welsh%20cricket">minor counties</a> cricket for Hertfordshire between 1959 and 1969, making 33 Minor Counties Championship appearances. He made his <a href="List%20A%20cricket">List A</a> debut against <a href="Devon%20County%20Cricket%20Club">Devon</a> in the 1st round of the <a href="1969%20Gillette%20Cup">1969 Gillette Cup</a>, scoring 19 runs before being dismissed by <a href="Robert%20Healey%20%28cricketer%29">Robert Healey</a>, in a match which Hertfordshire won by 98 runs. He made his second and final List A appearance in the second round of the same competition against <a href="Glamorgan%20County%20Cricket%20Club">Glamorgan</a>. In this match, he was dismissed for a duck by <a href="Malcolm%20Nash">Malcolm Nash</a>, with Glamorgan winning the match by 85 runs.
Hockey.
Jones played field hockey for Hertfordshire, <a href="Cambridge%20University%20Cricket%20Club">Cambridge University</a>, <a href="England%20men%27s%20national%20field%20hockey%20team">England</a> and <a href="Great%20Britain%20men%27s%20national%20field%20hockey%20team">Great Britain</a>, representing Great Britain in the <a href="1960%20Summer%20Olympics">1960</a> and the <a href="1964%20Summer%20Olympics">1964 Olympic Games</a>. He was manager of the England Schoolboy Hockey XI, between 1967 and 1974, manager of the England Hockey XI, between 1968 and 1969, and president of the English Schoolboys Hockey Association, between 1980 and 1988.
